text:
No doubt I'm still checking out regex basics, but I'm afraid this isn't
correct, at least not as expected:

Why do I have to use "$1" instead of "$2" to backreference the URL part
matched by the "(.*)" clause below (which is the 2nd parenthesis in the
regex)?

I've read a bit about "(?!...)" clauses, for example that they will
"match with zero length", but where am I told they do not count in the
backreference index?

In other words, is that behaviour really intentional?

My "httpd.conf" snippet:
---8<---
DocumentRoot <somewhere>
# still access the default content via this alias:
Alias /apache "E:\Apache2\htdocs"

<Location /server-info>
    SetHandler server-info
</Location>

# a vHost that handles all the "wrong" hostnames
# this box can be addressed with:
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName localhost
    ServerAlias myhost
    ServerAlias www.myhost.dom
 # exclude some content from beeing served via SSL:
    RedirectMatch ^/(?!apache|icons|error|manual|server\-info)(.*) \
        https://www.myhost.dom/$1
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *:443>
    ServerName www.myhost.dom
  # any alias hostnames would interfere
  # with the SSL cert assigned to this vHost

    DocumentRoot <somewhere-else>
    SSLEngine On
  # ...
</VirtualHost>
--->8---

Regards

OlafL

my keywords: mod_alias mod_rewrite RedirectMatch regex (?! backreference
